title: Hepatocellular Carcinoma Case
setup_script: A 58-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C and compensated cirrhosis presents for routine surveillance. An abdominal ultrasound shows a 2.5 cm lesion in segment VI of the liver. Alpha-fetoprotein is elevated. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident reviews liver function tests
dynamic_flow.reply: Child–Pugh A (bilirubin 1.2, albumin 3.5, INR 1.1, no ascites or encephalopathy).
Lesion demonstrates arterial enhancement with washout in venous phase, consistent with LI-RADS HCC.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for portal hypertension
dynamic_flow.reply: Endoscopy shows small varices; hepatic venous pressure gradient 9 mmHg (not clinically significant).
Options include resection, ablation, or transplantation, depending on portal hypertension and performance status.
Right segmentectomy performed with negative margins.
Tumor grows to 5.2 cm, no longer within Milan criteria for transplant eligibility.
Appropriate for unresectable lesions or as bridge to transplant.
Milan criteria: single lesion ≤5 cm or up to three lesions ≤3 cm without vascular invasion.
Abstinence from alcohol, vaccination against HAV/HBV, ongoing variceal screening.
Explains prognosis, recurrence risk, and importance of long-term follow-up.

critical_decision_points: Interpretation of imaging criteria for HCC.
Assessment of liver function and portal hypertension.
Selection of appropriate treatment modality (resection, ablation, transplant, TACE).
Understanding and application of Milan criteria.

rubric.resident_feedback_template: StrengthsYou demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing hepatocellular carcinoma and applying LI-RADS criteria. You appropriately considered surgical, ablative, and transplant options. Your communication was clear and organized. Areas for ImprovementEarlier articulation of transplant eligibility and bridging strategies such as TACE would strengthen your management plan. Consider refining the discussion of portal hypertension assessment and its impact on surgical candidacy.
